title: The Information Addict- Episode 1: Introduction
description:
Thanks so much for watching! 

Be sure to subscribe if you'd like to see more.

transcript_parts.text: [Music]
welcome to the very first
episode of the information addicts
podcast my name is cassidy i'm an
information addict and this is my
podcast where i explore information
ideas and beliefs and try to figure out
how to do that more responsibly
i'm really excited to finally be doing
this i feel like this has been a long
time coming for me
for those of you who have seen me around
the bridges of meaning discord or
paul's channel you know that i've
dabbled in podcasting a little bit
but i've finally decided to take the
leap and commit to something on my own
which is
scary and exciting all at the same time
and i think overall i'm looking forward
to
what this project is and how it will
evolve as i move forward
but before i get too much into the whole
structure and what i want this to be
i do want this first episode to be a
little bit more about myself
and my background to give you an idea of
who i am
one because if you're gonna sit and
listen to me ramble on the internet i
feel like it's only fair you have a
little bit of background but
i also think it gives a really helpful
understanding of how i got to where i am
and where it leads me
here into this project and where i want
to take it in the future
so like i said my name is cassidy i'm a
filmmaker i'm an entrepreneur
and for the sake of this podcast i am an
information addict
i can't say i have always had an issue
with information consumption
in fact most of my life i probably
avoided
trying to learn or process big ideas uh
full stop
uh it wasn't because there was any
insecurity or
feeling that i didn't want to know
things
or couldn't know things i think it was
just more
of a emotional immaturity at that time
where i didn't have the wherewithal
to take on the workload that it
took to process those ideas and really
think through
uh big questions and so i kind of went
more into an escapism of like youtube
binges
and netflix shows and
that definitely led me down a path where
i am now with an interest in media and
creating
film but i'm glad that i slowly
went out of that phase in college
i think there's a lot of reasons why it
sort of shifted for me
after i graduated high school i mean one
i think
the college learning situation
was something i was much more suited to
than any sort of
public middle school high school or even
private school that i'd ever gone to
because it wasn't like i was forced to
go through a program
i opted in to classes
that i had a choice to pick and it gave
me
this feeling of a participation in the
things that i was learning which was
really exciting
and i definitely think that the monetary
value of it all
really affected how i thought about it
having a scholarship and someone paying
me to go
to college classes sort of
changed my outlook and made me take it a
little bit more seriously and respect it
more but
at the end of the day i think ultimately
what created a big shift in me
was having an experience right after
graduation
that made me really confront my
relationship with truth
specifically on the question of god and
religion
so like most people in america i grew up
religious
grew up in a non-denominational
protestant home very
stereotypically so i think for a lot of
people who grew up
the way that i did they can often cite
it as being
a source of negativity and
made them dislike church but that
definitely wasn't my case it actually
sort of attracted me to it i think that
has a lot to do
with my parents i was able to see how
their belief in god created a lasting
change in their lives and switched the
direction
and made their lives better and made
them kinder more caring more thoughtful
people
and to me that was really appealing and
although i did believe it to be true it
was another thing that made me
want it to be true you know it's
interesting i think that
if you would ask me growing up if i was
a christian i probably would have said
yes with unwavering certainty but
when i started getting older i realized
that
my profession of faith was not really
lining up
with the way that i lived and that's not
to say i was living
this crazy immoral lifestyle i think for
most people
who would look at me they would describe
me as a
quote-unquote good person but
i knew that what i had known
christianity to be
and believed it to be with not really
being fulfilled
in the way that i was living and i had
this sort of lukewarm
approach to christianity that was
leaving me super unfulfilled
and i won't go through all of the
details but i had an experience that
made me really confront that
uh contradiction and realize how big of
a problem
it was and it kind of left me at this
crossroads
it was like i could keep going down this
road
of you know believing christianity but
not really
acting like i did and probably still
continue to feel unfulfilled
i could totally pivot and go down this
other road of hedonism
doing whatever i wanted living however i
saw fit
and i had known enough people who had
gone down that road
to realize that that road
where it ended left people more
unfulfilled
than the way that i felt now so it
didn't really seem like
a genuine option for me but the third
and final option that
i kind of saw at that moment was okay
well what if
i take this god thing seriously and i
run
at him with everything i have
and see if it makes a difference and
really live the life
that i claim to believe and
i chose that road and i kind of did it
without any expectations
just going down it saying well
this other thing's not working so let's
just give it a shot and
within six months i had realized that
although i didn't have a lot of
behavioral changes
my intention shift created this
exponential change that made me an
entirely different person
and for the first time i had a purpose
and i felt fulfilled and i felt
eager to take on the world and learn and
engage and that was a totally new
experience for me
and i think in that moment i sort of
started to realize
i really think
that god is real and like that that
moment made him real for me
and i kind of got convinced to keep
walking down that road
until someone conf could convince me i
should stop
and the only way that they could really
do that is to show me
a better truer path than the one i was
on
but i i wanted to just keep going and
follow that truth
so after walking that path i spent about
two and a half years at home
sort of following god trying to
understand what that means and then i
moved to the bay area to go to college
and i think that was the first time i
really found myself
in a place of uncomfortability
you know i was from this conservative
christian bubble put into this very
liberal
uh more spiritually open
city and while i was very eager
to have that experience i also was aware
of
the impact that could make on a faith
journey and in my beliefs in general
and so i i definitely took that with
some seriousness
and what i did very soon
after moving to the bay area a lot of
people who
grew up christian would probably say was
a red flag but
i decided very quickly that i wanted to
stop going to church every sunday
and it wasn't because i stopped
believing
it was more of this acknowledgement that
i had spent
the first 21 years of my life calling
myself a christian
in the safety of a church building and i
wanted to know what it meant
to be a christian outside of a building
and the more that i was reading the
gospels and
acts and seeing this early church the
more
i felt like the life that i was living
there
didn't really reflect the way jesus
lived and i wanted to bring more of that
into my life so
i continued to follow god and seek him
but i decided to instead of going to
church to start engaging other people
outside of my faith in questions and
conversations about religion
and what i found is that
i was not only learning more about what
other people believed in getting a
better understanding of how they thought
i was getting a lot of clarity on what i
believed
and deeper deeper nuance on the things
that i
held sacred and a lot of those
conversations were so life-giving
more life-giving than the ones that i
had had in church buildings and that was
really
attractive to me and so i kept chasing
that feeling
i spent two and a half years in the bay
area
doing this experiment and when i moved
to australia to study abroad i brought
that attitude with me
now i didn't know a lot of people when i
moved to australia i had
three bags an airbnb and a loose plan of
how i was gonna make it all work out and
i was definitely flying by the seat of
my pants and the
beginning of my time there it was harder
to connect with people but i did
end up connecting with a couple people
but one of them ended up being
a pretty militant atheist and
uh he he somehow found out it was
christian and started asking me
questions
and it started with just conversations
but eventually he gave me a book
called uh god is not great how
uh religion poisons everything by
christopher hitchens
when he handed me the book i remember
sitting in a lecture hall and just
feeling
a wave of fear sort of wash over my
whole body
and i remember thinking man there could
be something in this book
that makes me change my mind about the
things that i hold most sacred
and that was really scary but
in that same moment i knew that if i was
that scared
to read this book i probably should
and so i started reading the next day
and
i expected to not like the book and to
dislike the author but the more that i
read the more that i found christopher
hitchens to be
incredibly endearing yes he was very
brash and harsh
a lot of the time but there was a lot of
truth in the things that he said
and he asked tough questions a lot of
them
i didn't have good answers for and he
didn't change my mind about the god
question
but he got me to a place where i could
realize
how someone wouldn't believe in god
which was never something
that i could really
understand before because the idea of a
cosmic creator never bothered me
and um you know i read the book and
it definitely left me questions but you
know it def
it didn't change my mind i i think it
wasn't until two weeks later
when the presidential election happened
that something started
to switch in me and there started to be
uh more of a severity in the way that
in the shift of the way that i started
thinking
so uh when i went to australia i
wouldn't say i was
very political in fact i disliked
politics and i still disliked politics
in many ways
but i i just wasn't i wasn't aware
and i wasn't informed but going to
australia and being abroad during a very
divisive election
made me realize how important
our political system is around the world
and it definitely
changed my perspective and the way that
i should look at it and in a lot of ways
it became very difficult because people
would ask me questions about what was
going on
in the political system and i had no
idea and so i had to
work through all of these questions that
i didn't have answers for
and it was especially difficult with how
uh heated and uncomfortable that
that specific election was
but um all this to say when the
election day came i didn't want to look
at the results but i figured
i should be informed i'm gonna i'm gonna
check the results real quick
before i move on with my day and i meant
to be at the computer for five minutes
but i ended up staying there for two
hours just watching states turn red and
blue and eventually
seeing that trump had become president
and
i'll admit i was angry and a lot angrier
than i thought
i would be and i didn't understand why
now granted i was not a fan of trump um
but
that being said i wasn't a huge fan of
hillary either so the fact that he won
it didn't it didn't quite compute to the
level of
frustration that i was feeling and i
started to unpack that and try to
understand why am i feeling this thing
and at the end of the day i realized
i'm angry because i was told this could
never happen
i've been spoon fed this narrative that
trump could never be president
and i bought it without even questioning
it
and it started to get me thinking well
what else
have i been believing
without questioning it
and that thought led to a whole
host of unhealthy behaviors that
would lead to existential crises and
a lot of crumbling and confidence in the
things that i
could hold to be true so the next few
days after the election i started to
go on an information consumption binge
and
went into the spiral that was incredibly
unhealthy
and when i compare it now to what i had
done before
i can see that it wasn't this
genuine eager open search
to try to understand people and ideas
better
it became more of this control mechanism
to
help feel like my world would stop
crumbling
because that's really how it felt for a
long time that all of these things that
i had
believed for a long time were starting
to fall apart
and this foundation that i thought was
strong turned out to just be built on
toothpicks
and if i didn't do something quick
everything was going
to fall apart and
it led me to some really dark places and
it kind of got me
to the place where i started to realize
that
no matter how much i tried to stop it
it was going to fall apart it was going
to crumble
and there wasn't anything that i could
do about that
so instead of working towards
trying to fix this thing that was
falling apart
i kind of leaned into it and let it fall
and tried stripping everything away
so that i could rebuild my life
and my beliefs on things that i could
understand and
hold to be true the problem was
i didn't really know how to do that
so the last four years has been
this slow journey of trying to figure
out well how do i
come to an understanding of what is true
how do i build my beliefs
how do i consume information better and
i'll admit i've made a lot of mistakes
as i move through that
i think i've learned a lot and you know
i've come
to an understanding of better what i
believe and
today i still find myself to be a
christian but it's
a different version of that and it
it's still it's still in the process of
trying to reconstruct that and make it
something healthy um
you know i i think a lot of people have
been talking about deconstruction lately
and it often gets looked at in a
negative light
especially in christian communities in
atheist communities it's celebrated but
for christian communities there's this
fear of it and
you know i always found that fear to be
understandable
but not always helpful because i look at
my life and i see the way that
i deconstructed and find good in it
but because
i stripped everything away and rebuilt
and found
a better meaning if we leave everything
deconstructed yes that's a problem but
having that time to work through things
and reconstruct things is really good
and
i'd love to find a way to help people
embrace that more
so along for a long time i walked this
journey
alone trying to figure out
everything on my own in isolation and it
led me to insanity but in the last year
i have gotten connected with the bridges
of meeting discord community that was
launched from paul vander clay's channel
and it's been incredibly helpful
and helped me regain some of that
more positive side that i had seen
previously about the way that i consume
information and removed me away from
some of this addictive behavior
most of the time sometimes it's still
bad but
i've learned to put the tools in to help
me help me do it better
but um through that i have grown so much
and i feel like my
thoughts and ideas have expanded which
was a really good thing but i've
i've hit a wall here and i've started to
feel like
all of this stuff that's built up in my
head
need i i need to do something with it or
it's going to start to ooze out in
really negative ways
i felt like this probably for the last
six months
and you know i'm
finally led me here to doing this
podcast
as a way to kind of reorganize
reorganize my thoughts
and get a better handle
on what this is and working with others
to do those things
i'm excited to do all that but i'm
nervous to do it too but i
think that this will ultimately be
something that's a positive thing so if
you've gotten this far
and you want to
continue on a journey and feel
that you've had a similar experience
that i had i would love
for you to listen and go along with me
and help me
as i'm trying to figure out how to be
a more responsible information consumer
myself
okay so here's the deal the goal of this
podcast
is to be more intentional about what i'm
consuming and how i'm consuming
and the way that i'm using that to help
build my beliefs
and get to truth
the second overall goal is to work
with others who want the same thing
because i had spent so much time alone
and realizing the need to have
a community to get closer to ideas i
want that to be a big part
of what i'm doing here so ultimately
this podcast is going to come out in two
forms one
are going to be monologue videos like
this where i work through
ideas issues breakdown
things that i i find fascinating you
know
pretty loose and structured i don't i
don't want to be too tight in a box i
want this to evolve the way it needs to
but general general topic of information
and
and how we consume those sort of things
and the second type of videos are going
to be long-form conversations
a lot of them going to be with friends
family or just people i find interesting
and work together with people and and
talk about things that
you know we want to talk about and
unpack those things
and you know practice that
ability to work through ideas with
people you agree with and disagree with
and create a more civil conversation
so yeah like i said i want to keep it
loose as far as structure
because i've decided going into this i
only want to do this
as long as it keeps servicing myself and
other people
if it's not doing those things it can't
continue
the way that it is so that means it
either needs to evolve
in its form or function or
i need to rethink the way that i'm
producing content which may mean
shutting this down
and so i just want to create that room
where i don't feel like
i'm putting myself in a box and creating
it too tight of a formula
where it doesn't give it the ability to
grow you know i have a tendency
to run before i can walk which can often
lead me to a lot of fun and interesting
experiences
but there's a lot of negative sides to
it and definitely can lead to burnout
and i don't want that to happen with
this podcast
so to start i'm going to be releasing
once a week and
just trying to create things that i i
think are helpful and are servicing
myself
and we'll keep going and see what we go
from there but
as part of that i would love for anybody
who's watching and is engaged in this if
you have suggestions and there are
things that you want to hear
hear about or work through i want to do
that with you i want to be engaged in
that
so definitely feel free to
be a part of that in the comments and
reach out to kind of
make this service you as well so it's
not just me and we're working together
uh to do those things and
be more responsible at the way we're
consuming
so i've decided that i want to
end each episode by reciting the
serenity prayer
for a couple reasons the first of all i
figured
i should probably just lean in to this
shameless appropriation
of the aaa 12-step model and just give a
little homage to
the thing that has inspired this podcast
a little bit
but i also think that the words of that
prayer
have a lot to say about the way that we
consume information
and come to our beliefs and hold a lot
of wisdom in that journey and the
pursuit towards those things
so i want to keep those words in my mind
as i go
and continue to walk this journey and
trying to unpack
these really difficult
concepts and conversations so
that being said god grant me the
serenity to accept the things i cannot
change
the courage to change the things i can
and always seem to know the difference
thanks so much
